title: How to Season Vegetables for a Roast

steps.headline: Wash the vegetables with cold water.
Scrub and peel the vegetables thoroughly.
steps.description: Leave on the skins of the root vegetables where possible (for example, carrots, potatoes); doing so will retain some vitamins and add to the flavor of the dish. For other vegetables like onions and garlic, it is best to remove the peel.

steps.headline: Place the vegetables on a cutting board and cut all large vegetables into bite-size pieces.
steps.description: Leave whole the smaller vegetables like garlic cloves and baby beets or carrots. Cut the vegetables to a similar size, as this will help them cook at approximately the same rate.

steps.headline: Heat 2 tablespoons (30ml) of cooking oil on medium in a large frying pan.
Add the firm vegetables, such as carrots and potatoes, to the pan, sprinkle them with salt and pepper and sauté them for about 10 minutes or until they are crisp-tender.
Remove the firm sautéed vegetables form the pan and toss them into the roasting dish.
Sauté the remaining, softer vegetables, such as squash and onions, for about 5 minutes, or until crisp-tender.
Toss the rest of the vegetables into the roasting dish in preparation for roasting.
Put all the peeled and cut vegetables into a large bowl.
Drizzle fine-grade vegetable oil over the vegetables, using just enough oil to thinly coat them.
Sprinkle your favorite seasonings on the vegetables.
Mix the vegetables and seasonings well with your hands or use a mixing spoon.
steps.description: Mix well to ensure that the vegetables are evenly coated.

steps.headline: Add the seasoned vegetables to the roasting dish and continue cooking them in the oven for one hour, or for the amount of time your recipe states.

text: Seasoning Vegetables by Sautéing Wash the vegetables with cold water.  Scrub and peel the vegetables thoroughly. Leave on the skins of the root vegetables where possible (for example, carrots, potatoes); doing so will retain some vitamins and add to the flavor of the dish. For other vegetables like onions and garlic, it is best to remove the peel. Place the vegetables on a cutting board and cut all large vegetables into bite-size pieces. Leave whole the smaller vegetables like garlic cloves and baby beets or carrots. Cut the vegetables to a similar size, as this will help them cook at approximately the same rate. Heat 2 tablespoons (30ml) of cooking oil on medium in a large frying pan.  Add the firm vegetables, such as carrots and potatoes, to the pan, sprinkle them with salt and pepper and sauté them for about 10 minutes or until they are crisp-tender.  Remove the firm sautéed vegetables form the pan and toss them into the roasting dish.  Sauté the remaining, softer vegetables, such as squash and onions, for about 5 minutes, or until crisp-tender.  Toss the rest of the vegetables into the roasting dish in preparation for roasting.  Seasoning Vegetables without Sautéing Put all the peeled and cut vegetables into a large bowl.  Drizzle fine-grade vegetable oil over the vegetables, using just enough oil to thinly coat them.  Sprinkle your favorite seasonings on the vegetables.  Mix the vegetables and seasonings well with your hands or use a mixing spoon. Mix well to ensure that the vegetables are evenly coated. Add the seasoned vegetables to the roasting dish and continue cooking them in the oven for one hour, or for the amount of time your recipe states.
